Fig. 10 Enhancing oxygen reduction reaction with Pt-decorated Cu@Pd and high-entropy alloy catalysts: Insights from first-principles analysis of Pt arrangement Ming-Yi Chen Software Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft a Ngoc Thanh Thuy Tran Supervision Writing – review & editing b Ahmed Abubakar Alao Investigation Validation a Wen-Dung Hsu Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing a b c ⁎ a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan 701, Taiwan Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Cheng Kung University 1 University Road Tainan 701 Taiwan Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan 701, Taiwan b Hierarchical Green-Energy Materials (Hi-GEM) Research Center, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 701, Taiwan Hierarchical Green-Energy Materials (Hi-GEM) Research Center, National Cheng Kung University Tainan 701 Taiwan Hierarchical Green-Energy Materials (Hi-GEM) Research Center, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 701, Taiwan c Program on Semiconductor Packaging and Testing, Academy of Innovative semiconductor and Sustainable Manufacture, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 701, Taiwan Program on Semiconductor Packaging and Testing, Academy of Innovative semiconductor and Sustainable Manufacture, National Cheng Kung University Tainan 701 Taiwan Program on Semiconductor Packaging and Testing, Academy of Innovative semiconductor and Sustainable Manufacture, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan 701, Taiwan ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan 701, Taiwan. Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Cheng Kung University 1 University Road Tainan 701 Taiwan The efficiency of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) heavily relies on the surface Pt atom arrangement, which can be represented by the Pt-Pt average distance. Here, we employed density functional theory (DFT) to examine the influence of Pt arrangement on the ORR efficiency of Cu@Pd core-shell and high-entropy alloy catalysts. Our DFT calculations reveal that a shorter Pt-Pt average distance on the surface leads to a lower O2 dissociation barrier. Nevertheless, a shorter Pt-Pt average distance is not thermodynamically favored for the Cu@Pt catalyst. Moreover, we discovered a robust correlation between the level of the d-band center of the catalyst and the O2 adsorption energy. To explore the potential of controlling Pt arrangement, we investigated the use of NbMoTaW high-entropy alloy (HEA) substrates. Our findings suggest that HEA substrates provide promising surface chemistry for tuning Pt arrangement and controlling the O2 dissociation barrier. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords First-principles calculations Fuel cell Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) Electrocatalysts Core-shell structures High entropy alloy (HEA) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) are a promising energy conversion technology with applications in electric vehicles, stationary power sources, and portable devices. They offer advantages like low operating temperatures, quick start-up, and effective corrosion management through a solid membrane [1–3]. However, their commercialization faces challenges, including waste heat generation, sensitivity to fuel impurities, expensive catalysts, and slow oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) rates. The sluggish ORR kinetics lead to a substantial overpotential at the cathode, resulting in a 20–25% potential loss [4–8]. Catalyst selection is vital for performance enhancement and ORR mitigation, involving reactant adsorption, surface reactions, and product desorption. Adsorption energy of reactants is key; weak adsorption leads to sluggish reactions, while strong adsorption forms surface intermediates that slow the overall rate. Optimal adsorption energy is crucial for improved catalytic performance. Hammer and Nørskov's d-band center theory [9] predicts adsorption strength based on the electronic structure of the transition metal (adsorbent) and the molecular orbitals of the molecule (adsorbate). When the d-band center is close to the Fermi level, stronger adsorption occurs, creating an unoccupied anti-bonding state in the adsorbate. While Bhattacharjee et al. [10] noted limitations for systems with significant spin polarizations, the d-band center theory remains broadly applicable. Catalyst activity for ORR is assessed with the volcano plot introduced by Norskov et al.[9]. Pt and Pd are highly active but costly. Efforts to reduce their usage while maintaining efficiency including alloying with other metals or fabricating their thin films on cheaper substrates has been studied [11]. Besides that, single-site catalysts, composed of a few transition metal atoms on supporting materials, have shown promise in enhancing catalytic activity for various reactions. However, their stability and durability require improvement [12,13]. Core-shell structures, like Cu, Ni, or Co cores with Pd shells and Pt clusters on the surface [14,15], are cost-effective and offer improved stability and activity. Ab initio calculations suggest this is due to lattice compression of the Pd shell enhancing Pt's chemical stability and electron localization [15]. In the pursuit of reducing the utilization of platinum (Pt) as a critical catalyst, the examination of Pt's distribution, stability, and catalytic prowess on the substrate's surface assumes paramount importance. Regrettably, this field has not yet witnessed significant research efforts. Hence, the present study employs First-principles calculation techniques to delve into the catalytic models involving Pt atoms adsorbed onto a palladium (Pd) substrate, wherein copper (Cu) serves as the foundation material. Through the strategic manipulation of Pt's spatial arrangement and employing the Pt-Pt average distance as a pivotal descriptor, we meticulously compute the formation energy, oxygen adsorption energy, and oxygen dissociation energy barriers. This comprehensive analysis enables us to discern which Pt distribution configuration bestows optimal catalytic performance. Notably, the computational findings elucidate that the model characterized by the most proficient Pt distribution in terms of catalytic efficiency is accompanied by a concomitant elevation in formation energy. Consequently, our research endeavors are bifurcated, with the second facet concentrating on the exploration of alternative substrates capable of preserving heightened Pt catalytic efficiency while concurrently mitigating the associated formation energy. High-entropy alloys, characterized by their amalgamation of multiple elemental constituents within a solid-solution phase, are of particular interest in our quest. These alloys exhibit a multifaceted array of chemical properties, potentially conducive to achieving the optimal Pt distribution with a reduced formation energy. Among these alloys, the NbMoTaW high-entropy alloy has been empirically substantiated to possess remarkable attributes including superior stability, resistance to corrosion, and resistance to oxidation [16–18]. These salient characteristics make it an auspicious candidate as a substrate material in our study. Consequently, we have elected to utilize NbMoTaW as the substrate and conducted exhaustive calculations encompassing the formation energy of diverse Pt distribution models on this substrate, in tandem with the determination of the oxygen adsorption energy and the oxygen dissociation energy barrier. The culmination of our computational investigations incontrovertibly substantiates the capability of the NbMoTaW substrate in effectively stabilizing the most favorable Pt distribution pattern. This groundbreaking revelation potentially paves the way for a novel avenue in the realm of catalyst development. 2 Calculation methods The present study employed an ab initio method to investigate the effect of Pt arrangement on Cu@Pd catalyst for oxygen reduction. The calculations were performed using the commercially available Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP), which is based on a plane wave basis set. The interactions between the ionic cores and valence electrons were modeled using the projector-augmented wave (PAW) potential [19]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with parameterization of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was used as the exchange-correlation functional in this study [20]. The valence electrons of the elements considered, including Cu (Cu_pv)(3p63d104s1), Pd(4d10), Pt(5d96s1), and O(2s22p4), were included in the calculations. Due to the triplet state of the O2 molecule [21], spin-polarized calculations based on the theory proposed by Rudolf Zeller [22] were performed. A plane wave cut-off energy was expanded until a kinetic energy convergence of 460 eV was achieved. For the initial screening of the feasibility of Pt atomic arrangement on the Pd surface, a Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh sample for single-point calculation was set to 2 × 2 × 1. The screened models were subjected to surface relaxation and structural optimization on a 4 × 4 × 1 k-point mesh that was tested by the convergence test. The criterion for geometry optimization was defined as the action of the Hellman-Feynman forces on atoms that were less than 0.02 eV/Å. The construction of the Cu@Pd slab model involved two main steps: first, the optimization of the Cu/Pd interface bulk model, followed by the construction of the Cu/Pd slab model. The interface was established on the Cu(111)[110]//Pd(111)[110] orientation. The Cu/Pd slab model employed in this study consisted of an interface with a 4 × 4 supercell surface, incorporating three atomic layers of Cu at the base, and nine layers of Pd atop. The thickness of Cu and Pd was determined based on experimental results reported by Chen et al. [15]. The bulk lattice parameter of Cu and Pd is 3.628 Å and 3.936 Å, respectively. Initially, to address the lattice mismatch between Cu and Pd, the Pd lattice was compressed such that its lattice parameter in the (111) plane aligned with Cu(111). Subsequently, the Pd(111) model was placed onto the Cu(111) model, with the distance of the Pd-Pd equilibrium distance along the [111] direction, to form the interface bulk model. This interface bulk model was optimized, allowing both lattice and atomic positions to relax and obtain a minimum energy structure of the Cu/Pd interface bulk model. The final optimized model possesses a lattice parameter of 3.71 Å. The dimensions of the interface bulk model were 11.13 Å, 11.13 Å, and 40.04 Å along the [110], [101], and [111]-direction, respectively, with angles α = 90°, β = 90°, and γ = 120°. A vacuum layer of 15 Å was added to the interface bulk model to build the Cu/Pd slab model, which was tested to ensure that no slab replica interaction occurred. The model was then optimized again, allowing both lattice and atomic positions to relax. A final geometric representation of the Cu@Pd slab model is shown in Fig. 1. While our model used a flat surface to mimic the Cu@Pd core-shell particle surface, the surface area in the model was only about 1/1000 of that on actual particle surfaces in experiments. Nonetheless, a flat surface is a reasonable setup for modeling purposes. Prior to the decoration of Pt atoms on top, the middle three layers of Pd were fixed to save computation time. The present study investigates the effect of Pt arrangement on the oxygen adsorption and dissociation process in Cu@Pd slab models decorated with 3 (Pt3), 4 (Pt4), and 8 (Pt8) Pt atoms. These models were considered based on the catalyst synthesized by Chen et al. [15], and were constructed using both adsorption and embedding types (refer to Fig. S1 in the supplementary material). The Pt3, Pt4, and Pt8 models have an equivalent average area density of 0.0279 atoms/Å2, 0.0372 atoms/Å2, and 0.07441 atoms/Å2, respectively. The effect of Pt arrangement was examined by testing different ranges of Pt-Pt average distance in each model, which was 1.61–5.56 Å, 2.00–5.20 Å, and 2.78–3.21 Å for the Pt3, Pt4, and Pt8 models, respectively. The formation energies of Pt adsorption and embedding models were derived using Eqs. 11a, and 11b, respectively. The O2 adsorption and dissociation energy were calculated by Eqs. 12 and 13, (11a) E f _ ads = ( E tot − E substrate − n Pt μ Pt ) / N (11b) E f _ emb = ( E tot − E substrate − n Pt μ Pt + n Pd μ Pd ) / N (12) E ads = E tot − E adsorbate − E surface (13) E diss = E tot , dissociation − E tot , no dissociation where E tot is the total energy of the system, E substrate represents the total energy of Cu@Pd substrate; μ Pt and μ Pd are the chemical potential energies of Pt and Pd and are of the unit eV/atom. They were obtained from the total energy of the bulk Pt and Pd models. E surface is the total energy of the slab model before O2 adsorption, while E adsorbate is the energy of the O2 molecule. Models for O2 adsorption on the Pt4 adsorbed/embeded Cu@Pd slab refer to Fig. S2 and S3 in the supplementary material, respectively. To examine the stability of each system, ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations coupled with NVT canonical ensemble, with a temperature of 373 K, a time step of 1 fs, and a total simulation time of 225 ps were employed [23,24]. The Fermi level and work function calculation were also carried out to further characterize the effect of Pt arrangement on the oxygen adsorption/dissociation process. The dissociation barrier of O2 was determined via the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method, with the initial configuration obtained from the O2 adsorption on the relaxed Pt adsorption and embedding Cu@Pd slab models. The final configuration was derived from the equilibrium state of the ab-initio molecular dynamics snapshots. The electron transfer from the oxygen molecule to the slab was verified using Bader Charge analysis. The energies of d-band centers were calculated using Eq. 14, [25,26]. (14) ε d = ∫ m M ε ∙ ρ ε d ε ∫ m M ρ ε d ε where ε is the electron energy and ρ(ε) is the density of state, and M and m are the maximum and minimum energy levels of the d-orbital, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of Pt/Cu@Pd model Using work function difference between the substrate and the metal for deposition as a measure of model stability is indeed a good descriptor, especially when the synthesis methods involve redox reactions. Generally, when two materials with significant differences in work function come into contact and form an interface, there is a greater electron transfer at the interface, making it more stable. Therefore, work function difference serves as a direct descriptor for interface stability. In this study, various models of Pt adsorption/embedding on a Cu@Pd substrate were considered, a strong correlation between their formation energy and work function difference was also found (shown as Fig. S4). Therefore, both work function difference and formation energy are excellent descriptors for assessing the stability of interface models. Since the calculation of formation energy is relatively straightforward, we chose to use it as our evaluation method in this study. According to the definition in Eq, 11(a), the formation energy of Pt adsorbed on the Cu@Pd slab model is the relative energy of the model with Pt adsorption to that of Pt bulk and Cu@Pd slab, and thus represents the stability of Pt adsorbed on the Cu@Pd slab. Similarly, the formation energy calculated in Eq. 11(b) for Pt embedding on the surface of Pd in the Cu@Pd slab model is the relative energy of the model with Pt surface embedding to that of Pt bulk, Pd bulk, and Cu@Pd slab, and thus represents the stability of Pt embedding on the surface of Pd and embedded in the Cu@Pd slab. A positive formation energy indicates that the product is thermodynamically unstable, and the more negative the formation energy, the more thermodynamically stable the product is. Fig. 2 shows the formation energies of Pt3, Pt4, and Pt8 adsorbed or surface-embedded in the Cu@Pd slab model, along with the formation energies of Pt3, Pt4, and Pt8 in different surface arrangments when adsorbed or surface-embedded. When Pt is in the surface adsorption state, the results show that the formation energy of Pt8 is positive, that of Pt4 is positive when the average Pt-Pt distance is less than 2.53 Å, and that of Pt3 is positive when the average Pt-Pt distance is less than 1.5 Å. This indicates that the more evenly dispersed Pt atoms are in the adsorption state, the more thermodynamically stable they are. This result was also confirmed by ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, and the results were shown in Fig. S5. In these simulations, Pt4 clusters initially adsorbed on the surface were simulated under NVE and NVT ensemble conditions, and after 10 ps, the Pt4 clusters decomposed into Pt atoms dispersed on the surface of the Cu@Pd slab. When Pt is in the surface embedding state, the shortest distance is greater than 2.7 Å because the embedding position depends on the surface sites of Pd, and the formation energy does not significantly change with the variation of the average Pt-Pt distance, but is more related to the surface density of Pt. For example, when Pt is in the embedding state, the formation energy of Pt8 is higher (less negative) than that of Pt4 and Pt3. Overall, the surface embedding state of Pt is more stable than the adsorption state, with a formation energy of about 0.04–0.08 eV lower. This result is consistent with the study by Zhuang et al.[14]. When Pt is in the adsorption state, the Pt atoms tend to be dispersed on the surface, while when Pt is in the surface embedding state, a lower Pt surface density leads to more stable results. Given that the Pt4 model affords the greatest number of configurations upon tuning the Pt-Pt average distance, it was selected as the model of choice for subsequent calculations within the scope of this study. 3.2 Adsorption of O2 molecule and its relationship with the d-band center Xu et al. and Zhuang et al. [14,27] have extensively examined and discussed several potential heterogeneities of oxygen adsorption sites. According to their calculations, the Pt-Pt bridge site is the most stable adsorption site, with the O2 molecule's orientation parallel to the bridge direction. Fig. 3 illustrates the oxygen adsorption energy at the bridge sites of the Pt4 adsorbed and surface-substituted Cu@Pd slab model. The bridge sites considered here include Pt-Pt, Pd-Pt, and Pd-Pd types, as depicted in Figs. S2 and S3. The findings indicate that the adsorption energy is only slightly influenced by the type of bridge site but is significantly altered by the average Pt-Pt distance. This suggests that there is only limited site preference for O2 molecule adsorption on the Pt4 adsorbed and surface-embedded Cu@Pd slab surface, which is a desirable trait for a high-performance catalyst. Furthermore, the adsorption or surface embedding of Pt atoms on the Cu@Pd slab surface also plays a crucial role in O2 adsorption. Similar results have been reported by Zhuang et al. [14] Specifically, an increase in the Pt-Pt distance would facilitate the adsorption of the O2 molecule, and O2 adsorption is more favored for the Pt adsorption models than for the Pt embedding models. Besides, increasing the thickness of the core layer results in dwindling site-dependent adsorption energy. Regarding the relationship between the O2 adsorption energy and the d-band center of the Pt4 adsorbed and surface-substituted Cu@Pd models, as shown in Fig. 4, the O2 adsorption energy is found to be a negative correlation to the d-band center energy of the catalyst, a finding which is consistent with earlier work reported by Zhuang et al. [14]. Specifically, a more negative d-band center energy leads to a lower likelihood of O2 adsorption on the catalyst surface. To elucidate the influence of the d-band center on the adsorption energy, we selected four extreme cases, labeled (a), (b), (c), and (d) and circled in yellow in Fig. 4, which correspond to the Pt4 adsorbed and surface-substituted Cu@Pd models with the lowest and highest d-band center energy, and performed a detailed DOS analysis. The results of this analysis are presented in Fig. 5(a)-(d). The density of states (DOS) and partial DOS (PDOS) of the lowest (most negative) and highest (least negative) d-band centers of the Pt4 adsorbed Cu@Pd models, prior to O2 molecule adsorption, are shown in Fig. 5(a) and 5(b), respectively. Fig. 5(e) and 5 (f) depict the DOS plots after the adsorption of the O2 molecule onto the Figs. 5(a) and 5(b) models, respectively. Bonding and antibonding states have been indicated in the figures. An additional DOS peak between the bonding and antibonding states is present following adsorption, which is due to the coupling between the p-orbital of the O2 molecule and the d-orbital of Pt4 adsorbed Cu@Pd slab. The d-band center theory posits that the energy level of the d-band center and the Fermi level of the adsorbent can be used to determine whether it is favorable for an adsorbate to adsorb. If the d-band center is slightly lower than the Fermi level, the adsorbent surface is favored for adsorbate adsorption, since the anti-bonding state would be unoccupied upon adsorption. Fig. 5(a) and 5(b) reveal that the d-band center is lower than the Fermi level, indicating that both cases have negative adsorption energy. Fig. 5(e) and (f) also show that their antibonding states are all higher than the Fermi level following O2 molecule adsorption. The energy difference between the d-band center and the Fermi level is − 1.62 eV and − 1.75 eV for Fig. 5(a) and 5(b), respectively. The corresponding adsorption energy of (a) and (b) in Fig. 4, respectively, exhibit a large (more negative) and small (less negative) value, in agreement with the predictions of the d-band center theory. Similar outcomes were obtained for the case of Pt4 surface-substituted Cu@Pd models. Specifically, the energy difference between the d-band center and the Fermi level is − 1.67 eV and − 1.72 eV for the strong and weak adsorptions, as indicated in (c) and (d) in Fig. 4, and shown as Fig. 5(c) and 5(d), respectively. Similar PDOS of O2 after adsorption was found shown in Fig. 5(g) and (h). Although we also explored the relationship between the O2 adsorption energy and work function, no significant correlation was found. 3.3 NEB calculation for O2 dissociation process The transition energy during O2 dissociation of Pt4 adsorbed and surface-substituted Cu@Pd models was investigated using NEB calculations ( Fig. 6(a) and (b), respectively). The 0th reaction coordinate denotes O2 molecule adsorption on the slab surface, while the 5th reaction coordinate represents the two dissociative O atoms adsorbed on the slab surface. The transition state is at the 3rd reaction coordinate. A positive correlation was observed between the dissociation barrier and the d-band center, as shown in Fig. 7. The more stable the adsorption of the O2 molecule is, the higher the dissociation barrier. 3.4 Charge analysis Fig. 8(a)-(c) depict the charge difference plot of the Pt4 substituted Cu@Pd models before and after the adsorption of an O2 molecule. The redistribution of charges mainly occurs at the topmost two layers of the Pt4 substituted Cu@Pd slab, approximately 2.29 Å. The range of charge redistribution on the surface is within a radius of 3.25 Å from the center of the O2 molecule, which is approximately 1.42 times the depth. The coverage of the charge redistribution encompasses 60% of the longest Pt-Pt distances in the study. Thus, regardless of the adsorption site, the adsorption energy is similar due to similar interacted adsorbent transition metal atoms, as shown in Fig. 3. Based on this information, the maximum adsorption density for the O2 molecule without neighbor adsorbate interference is estimated as 0.1 molecule/Å2. As illustrated in Fig. 8(d)-(f), the range of charge redistribution during O2 molecule dissociation is similar to that during O2 molecule adsorption, indicating that the dissociation is also a local reaction. The impact area has a radius of about 3–4 Å and a depth of 2–3 Å. Similar results were found for the O2 adsorption on the Pt4 adsorbed Cu@Pd models. Bader charge analysis was conducted to investigate the valence charge of the O atom and its corresponding Pt atom during O2 molecule adsorption and dissociation on the Pt4 adsorbed ( Fig. 9(a)) and surface-substituted (Fig. 9(b)) Cu@Pd slab models, including the charges at the transition state. The results demonstrate that the absolute valence charge of the dissociated O atoms is the largest, followed by the O atom of the O2 molecule and the O* (O atoms at transition state) with the smallest charge. The Pt atoms show similar results, but with opposite signs, and are not presented. The results are strongly correlated with the interaction strength between the O atom and the countered metal atoms. A higher valence charge indicates a more stable adsorbent adsorption. Furthermore, Our data (not shown) indicate that the shallower the d-band center, the greater the charge exchange between the adsorbed O2 molecule atoms and the countered metal atoms, leading to a higher valence charge of the O atom. These findings provide an explanation for the results presented in Fig. 4, which show that a shallower d-band center results in a more stable adsorption of the O2 molecule. The relationship between the dissociation barrier, as illustrated in Fig. 7, and the charge analysis can be inferred; however, this connection is indirect and is influenced by the difference in the valence charge of the O atom between the O atom of the adsorbed O2 molecule and the corresponding O atom at the transition state. The barrier height is associated with the charge difference, and this connection can be identified by comparing the data presented in Fig. 9(a) and (b) with that in Fig. 7, for both Pt adsorption and embedding models. 3.5 Design of the better catalyst The findings in Sections 3.2 to 3.4 indicate that to decrease the energy barrier of oxygen dissociation, it is necessary for platinum atoms to form clusters, with smaller Pt-Pt average distance resulting in better performance. However, AIMD and other thermodynamic calculations demonstrate that Pt atoms do not tend to cluster. As a result, an alternative solution is necessary to achieve optimal catalyst design. The utilization of high-entropy alloys (HEA) as substrates for enhancing the clustering of Pt atoms is investigated as an alternative solution for catalyst design. HEAs are known for their high chemical stability and diverse chemical bonding environments, which could potentially aid in improving the formation of Pt clusters on their surface. To this end, Pt4 adsorbed NbMoTaW HEA substrates with varying arrangements were constructed and their formation energies were calculated ( Fig. 10(a)). The model of the NbMoTaW substrate can be found in Fig. S6 in the supplemental materials, while the arrangements of Pt4 on the HEA substrate are consistent with those shown in Fig. S1C. The data in Fig. 10(a) are based on the lowest energy model for each Pt-Pt average distance case. The results indicate that all of the Pt4-adsorbed NbMoTaW substrate models have negative formation energies, even for models with an Pt-Pt average distance of less than 2.53 Å. This suggests that HEA substrates do enhance the formation of Pt clusters on their surface. Although the formation energies of models with shorter Pt-Pt average distances are higher than those with longer distances, the difference between the shortest and longest Pt-Pt average distance models becomes smaller with increasing Nb and Mo composition. Specifically, the difference decreases from 0.027 eV for equimolar NbMoTaW substrate to only 0.014 eV for Nb0.4Mo0.4Ta0.1W0.1 substrate. This energy difference range is in the range of room temperature, indicating a high probability of having the Pt4 cluster on the corresponding substrate. The binary formation of Pt-Nb and Pt-Mo is found to be more negative than other pairs, enabling the tuning of HEA composition to achieve desired Pt-adsorbed configurations. These findings demonstrate the advantage of using HEA as a substrate for catalyst design. Fig. 10(b) presents the relationship between the Pt-Pt average distance and the d-band center, which is further depicted in Fig. 10(c) in terms of the oxygen adsorption energy. Specifically, our findings reveal that a larger Pt-Pt average distance is associated with a shallower d-band center and a higher negative oxygen adsorption energy. Moreover, we observed that by modifying the composition of NbMoTaW substrates from equimolar to higher Nb and Mo contents (ranging from 0.25 to 0.4), the d-band center can be lowered by 4.49%, thereby increasing the stability of O2 adsorption by 2.37%. Fig. 10(d) depicts the correlation between the O2 adsorption energy and the d-band center for HEA substrates. The results demonstrate that the d-band center theory remains applicable to HEA substrates, suggesting that a shallow d-band center results in a stronger adsorption of the O2 molecule. However, the slope of the correlation varies depending on the substrate material. For instance, the slope for Pt4 adsorbed Cu@Pd models is − 5.35, which is higher than that for Pt4 adsorbed NbMoTaW HEA models of − 1.38. These findings indicate that while the d-band center theory can qualitatively predict the O2 adsorption strength, the quantitative energy is still dependent on the material properties. It is noteworthy that the Pt4-adsorbed NbMoTaW HEA substrate exhibits a lower oxygen adsorption energy at a shallower d-band center compared to the Pt4-adsorbed Cu@Pd substrate. In the context of the desired generation of Pt4 clusters on the substrate, the HEA substrate demonstrates a clear thermodynamic advantage (as depicted in Fig. 10(a)). Thus, it can be concluded that the HEA substrate holds great potential as a next-generation catalyst substrate and is worthy of further development. Fig. 10(e) presents a plot depicting the relationship between the d-band center and the oxygen dissociation energy barrier for various models employed in this study. It can be observed that the equimolar NbMoTaW HEA substrate exhibits a similar dissociation energy barrier to that of the Cu@Pd substrate for Pt4 adsorption with the minimum Pt-Pt average distance. However, the former demonstrates thermodynamic stability, as its formation energy is negative, unlike the latter. Comparing the Pt4 adsorbed Cu@Pd substrate with similar thermodynamic stability conditions, using NbMoTaW as the substrate can reduce the oxygen dissociation energy barrier by up to 0.184 eV which is equivalent to 23.3%. Furthermore, considering the influence of Pt4 distribution on thermodynamic stability, NbMoTaW with a higher Nb and Mo content can achieve a higher probability of Pt4 cluster formation. Moreover, its oxygen dissociation energy is still lower than that of the Pt4-adsorbed Cu@Pd substrate that meets the least thermodynamic stability condition. Based on these findings, it can be inferred that high-entropy substrates will exhibit superior oxygen dissociation catalytic performance. Therefore, the development of high-entropy substrates as catalysts is a promising direction that deserves further attention. To explore the impact of the surface distribution of Nb, Mo, Ta, and W at the top-most surface layer, the ATA-SQS software was utilized to establish three different models under the same total composition ratio of Nb, Mo, Ta, and W, as depicted in Fig. S7. In model A, the surface ratio of Nb, Mo, Ta, and W is 7:4:4:1, in model B it's 6:5:3:2, and in model C it's 4:3:4:5. Table S1 listed the formation energy and d-band center of the three Pt4 adsorbed NbMoTaW slab models. The O2 adsorption energy, and O2 dissociation barrier on the three Pt4 adsorbed NbMoTaW slab model are also listed. The formation energy falls within the range of − 0.008 eV to − 0.019 eV (a difference of 0.01 eV). This range accounts for approximately only 33% of the range for the formation energy when varying Pt4 distribution on the same substrate. Thus, the distribution of surface elements does not significantly affect our conclusion about which Pt4 distribution is more stable. The differences in the d-band center, O2 adsorption energy, and O2 dissociation barrier between the three models are only 3.3%, 2.1%, and 1.8%, respectively. Therefore, for the NbMoTaW substrate, the distribution of surface elements does not impact the current conclusions. This is consistent with the results in Fig. 8 because the range of O2 adsorption effects extends to a radius of 3–4 Å and a depth of 2–3 Å, encompassing approximately 20 atoms, which is sufficient to approximate the overall composition ratio in a complete solid solution. However, for HEAs that are prone to forming short-range order (SRO), this may have an influence on the results, and these discussions will be a focus of future research. 4 Conclusion This study investigates the impact of Pt arrangement on the dissociation energy barrier of O2 molecules on the Pt4 adsorbed and surface-substituted Cu@Pd slab surface. Our calculations reveal that the geometric arrangement of Pt atoms significantly influences the energy required for oxygen adsorption and dissociation. The stability of oxygen adsorption directly correlates with the energy barrier for oxygen decomposition. Our findings are supported by additional analysis techniques, such as Nudged Elastic Band (NEB), Bader charge analysis, and d-band center calculations. Our results indicate that the average Pt-Pt distance affects the d-band center, which influences the stability of oxygen adsorption and the height of the dissociation barrier. We explain this phenomenon through the valence charge and its transfer between the adsorption state and transition state. We conclude that designing and synthesizing efficient catalysts requires controlling the arrangement of Pt atoms on the catalyst surface. Although Pt atoms are stable on the Pd substrate surface when evenly spread, clustering Pt structures are the most efficient catalysts. Hence, we suggest exploring new support materials instead of Pd, as previous literature has shown the impact of support on catalytic efficiency. Our newly designed catalyst, NbMoTaW high-entropy alloy substrate adsorbed with Pt4, effectively enhances Pt4 cluster formation and maintains a relatively low dissociation barrier without compromising the catalytic performance. Our findings demonstrate the potential of high-entropy alloys as promising catalyst substrates. CRediT authorship contribution statement Wen-Dung Hsu: Conceptualization, Methodology. Appendices In general, the anode and cathode half-reaction of PEMFC can be expressed as reactions (1) and (2), respectively. (1) H 2 → 2 H + + 2 e − (2) 2 H + + 2 e − + 1 2 O 2 → H 2 For the half-reaction on the cathode, Norskov et.al and Nie et.al [9,28] proposed two mechanisms of ORR, dissociative mechanism and associative mechanism. Both mechanisms contribute a similar effect on the overpotential of ORR. In the dissociative mechanism, the O 2 molecule first adsorbs on the cathode surface and dissociate to O atom, O ads , shown as reaction (3). (3) 1 2 O 2 → O ads The O ads atom then reacted with the proton (H+) and electron that both formed at the anode but passed through the proton exchange membrane (PEM) and the outside circuit, respectively. Hence the reduction reaction of O ads occur to form create the Hydroxyl ( H O ads ) groups at the cathode shown as reaction (4). (4) O ads + H + + e − → H O ads Then, the Hydroxyl groups would react with the proton and electron again to form the H2O molecule and leave the cathode surface shown as reaction (5). (5) H O ads + H + + e − → H 2 O On the other hand, in the associative mechanism, the O 2 molecule directly adsorbed onto the cathode surface without dissociation shown as reaction (6). (6) O 2 → O 2 , ads Then, similar to the dissociative mechanism, the adsorbed O2 molecule reacts with the proton and electron to form the H O 2 , ads shown as reaction (7). The H O 2 , ads , then react with the proton and electron again to form the H2O2 or H2O and O ads shown as reaction (8). The H2O2 or H2O eventually desorb from the cathode surface. The O ads atom then could proceed reactions (4) and (5) mentioned in the dissociative mechanism. (7) O 2 , ads + H + + e − → H O 2 , ads (8) H O 2 , ads + H + + e − → H 2 O + O ads or H 2 O 2 The density functional theory (DFT) calculations provided by Norskov et.al [9] suggest that if a bias (electrode potential) larger than 0.78 V is applied to the system, the reaction steps from reaction (3) to (5) are not easy to occur due to formation of reaction barrier between reaction (4) and (5); but, if the bias is below 0.78 V, the reaction from (3) to (5) becomes spontaneous due to downhill reactions (for more details, please see the Supporting Information). This is because the adsorption of O2 molecule on the cathode at high potential is stable, resulting in high activation barrier for the dissociation process. Besides, Norskov et.al [9] also found that O2 coverage also affects the barrier height of the dissociative mechanism, in which the barrier of the reaction increases/decreases with the high/low O2 coverage. The calculated data reported by Subramanian et.al [29] and Sha et.al [30] shows O2 dissociation barrier in the gas phase is 0.57 eV when the O2 coverage is in the dilute limit. In addition, the solvent effect will contribute to the O2 dissociation barrier. The corresponding DFT calculation research done by Sha et.al [31] estimated that the O2 dissociation barrier of reaction (3) would decrease from 0.58 eV to 0.27 eV with the water as a solvent in the system. On the other hand, if OH- appears in the water, the barrier of reaction (4) will increase from 0.73 eV to 1.09 eV, which becomes the rate-determining step in the total ORR. Research reported by Li et.al [32] suggested that the pH value also affects the energy barrier in total ORR. The increasing concentration of [OH-] is detrimental to the ORR due to the barrier in reaction (4). coredata.dc:description: The efficiency of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) heavily relies on the surface Pt atom arrangement, which can be represented by the Pt-Pt average distance. Here, we employed density functional theory (DFT) to examine the influence of Pt arrangement on the ORR efficiency of Cu@Pd core-shell and high-entropy alloy catalysts. Our DFT calculations reveal that a shorter Pt-Pt average distance on the surface leads to a lower O2 dissociation barrier. Nevertheless, a shorter Pt-Pt average distance is not thermodynamically favored for the Cu@Pt catalyst. Moreover, we discovered a robust correlation between the level of the d-band center of the catalyst and the O2 adsorption energy. To explore the potential of controlling Pt arrangement, we investigated the use of NbMoTaW high-entropy alloy (HEA) substrates. Our findings suggest that HEA substrates provide promising surface chemistry for tuning Pt arrangement and controlling the O2 dissociation barrier.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing oxygen reduction reaction with Pt-decorated Cu@Pd and high-entropy alloy catalysts: Insights from first-principles analysis of Pt arrangement
